title: When will a nominee for FBI director be confirmed by the U.S. Senate?
preds:
Some OSINT in recent news reports related to this question: “Trump pressures Sessions to replace the acting FBI director,” Los Angeles Times, July 26. http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-trump-pressures-sessions-to-replace-the-1501080284-htmlstory.html

“Former officials say something 'insidious' is brewing between the White House and DOJ,” Business Insider, July 28. http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-sessions-white-house-justice-department-2017-7 “Senators prepare bill to block firing of special counsel,” Associated Press on Chicago Tribune, July 27. http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-special-counsel-20170727-story.html  “Report: Russian Propaganda Czar Was Murdered in D.C. Before Planned 2015 Meeting With Feds,” Slate, July 27. http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2017/07/28/report_mikhail_lesin_russian_rt_founder_was_murdered_in_d_c_in_2015.html “'Terrible Crimes' Made Putin World's Richest Person, Financier Testifies,” Voice of America, July 27. https://www.voanews.com/a/terrible-crimes-made-putin-world-richest-person-financier-tells-senators/3961955.html
I guess I had been right in my thinking to begin with. this isn't happening.

Time running out for full vote before Aug. 1. Many in Congress may have even more questions about Wray due to the challenging circumstances at hand. It seems he will be approved, but maybe there is no rush -- especially as Trump attacks acting FBI director McCabe, among others: Recent related news reports and OSINT: “Can a US President Be Charged With a Crime? It's Complicated,” Voice of America, July 27. https://www.voanews.com/a/can-a-us-president-be-charged-with-a-crime/3961703.html “The President’s Pardons Paradox: Granting Them Could Aid the Prosecution,” Just Security, July 28. https://www.justsecurity.org/43568/presidents-pardons-paradox-granting-aid-prosecution/ “Trump job approval swings lower,” The Hill, July 28. http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/344298-trump-job-approval-swings-lower “Anthony Scaramucci Called Me to Unload About White House Leakers, Reince Priebus, and Steve Bannon,” The New Yorker, July 26. http://www.newyorker.com/news/ryan-lizza/anthony-scaramucci-called-me-to-unload-about-white-house-leakers-reince-priebus-and-steve-bannon “Russia Orders US to Reduce Diplomatic Staff,” Voice of America, July 28. https://www.voanews.com/a/russia-orders-us-to-reduce-diplomatic-staff/3962689.html

This is not happening before Monday. After the failure of the healthcare bills, McConnell invoked cloture on only one nominee for a floor vote on Monday afternoon. More simply put, the Senate will not vote on Wray on Monday, meaning his confirmation will come after 1 August.
I got that wrong... There may be no path forward for healthcare as it failed 49-51 so on to nominations now.

Looks like it will be bumped back past Aug. 1.  Related news reports and OSINT: “Christie's Secret Arrangement With FBI Nominee Draws Scrutiny,” WNYC, July 25. http://www.wnyc.org/story/nj-assemblyman-calls-christies-secret-bridgegate-lawyer-serious-breach/ “Read the FBI’s guide to how Soviet spies recruit American assets,” Muckrock, July 21. https://www.muckrock.com/news/archives/2017/jul/21/fbi-soviet-recruitment/ "Trump approval rating dips to 35 percent, new poll finds,” CBS News, July 26. http://www.cbsnews.com/news/poll-trump-approval-rating-dips-to-35-percent/ "Graham: Firing Mueller would be 'beginning of the end' of Trump's presidency,” Politico, July 27. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/27/lindsey-graham-trump-robert-mueller-241027 “War Inside the White House: Scaramucci Takes on Priebus Over ‘Leaks,’” NBC News, July 27. http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/war-inside-white-house-n787001
It is July 27 today, making 31 july a difficult target.

Time appears to be running out for full vote on Wray before Aug. 1. Lots of factors involved that seem to get more interesting each day. Related OSINT: “Trump Attacks Sessions Again, This Time Over the Acting F.B.I. Director,” New York Times, July 26. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/us/politics/jeff-sessions-trump-mccabe.html “Republican Senators Steamed Over Trump Attacks Back Sessions,” NBC News, July 26. http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/republican-senators-steamed-over-trump-attacks-back-sessions-n786686 “Poll: Only 1 in 4 sure Trump will serve entire term,” The Hill, July 26. http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/343487-poll-only-1-in-4-think-trump-will-serve-entire-term “Trump's approval is underwater in 11 states he won in November,” CNN, July 26. http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/26/politics/trump-approval-underwater-11-states/index.html “Justice Dept. Nominee Says He Worked on Russian Bank’s Trump-Related Inquiry,” New York Times, July 26. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/us/politics/brian-benczkowski-justice-department-nominee-russia-bank.html

It appears the distinguished Senators are planning to spend the remaining work days of this month fulminating about health care.  This will end not with a bang but a whimper (and of course a barrage of midnight Twits), and they will slog on to real business some time early August.  This nomination should be high on the list then, unless their Fearful Leader instructs them that a futile foray into tax reform is more urgently required by the White House.    It was of course the spineless among the Senate Republicans who created this situation and now must wallow in it.  One strives mightily to feel sorry for them; so far, nothing.

According to C-SPAN last night (yes, I've resorted to watching paint dry), there's about 18 hours of debate remaining on health care to be held today and tomorrow. If that's the case, and somehow the Senate wraps health care up one way or another (and keeps their recess delayed until mid-Aug), it's possible for Wray to be confirmed on 31 July.  However, my Rube Goldberg confirmation scheme relies on a lot of "ifs" to happen. And the Senate's track record doesn't generally follow my thought process. I'll give them 3% as of now, but today's floor activity will likely be contentious and continue to dominate all capacity for thought for the Senate.
This won't turn out well for.

Going down in forecast to August as healthcare focus/obsession by McConnell continues.  Cloture was not invoked today for Christopher Wray which may indicate that it's not a priority as partisan healthcare repeal will likely be hammered throughout out the week, likely without other distractions ie. big stuff such as Trump nominee, Christopher Wray.  The Senate Democrats calendar for Wednesday reveals quite a bit of detail as to how things will be voted upon tomorrow. 
https://democrats.senate.gov/2017/07/25/schedule-for-wednesday-july-26-2017/ The Senate stands adjourned until 9:30am on Wednesday, July 26, 2017. Following Leader remarks, the Senate will resume consideration of H.R.1628, the American Health Care Act of 2017 (Republican reconciliation bill) with approximately 17 hours of debate remaining (8’ 32” per side). The time from 9:30am until 11:30am will be equally divided between the managers or their designees. At 11:30am Senator Murray, or designee, will be recognized to make a point of order against Paul amendment #271 (ACA repeal) and Senator Enzi, or designee, will be recognized to make a motion to waive. Following the motion to waive, the Senate will vote in relation to Paul SA #271. Following disposition of the amendment, the time until 3:30pm will be equally divided on the Murray or designee motion to commit with a vote on the motion at 3:30pm.  Upon disposition of the Murray motion, Senator Murray or her designee (Casey) will be recognized to offer an additional motion to commit. Wednesday, July 26th at 11:30am – 2 roll call votes Motion to waive points of order with respect to Paul amendment #271
Adoption of Paul amendment #271 (ACA repeal) Wednesday, July 26th at 3:30pm – 1 roll call vote Donnelly motion to commit (protecting Medicaid)

Amendments pending to H.R.1628, American Health Care Act of 2017 McConnell SA #267 (repeal ACA and to cure Byrd rule violations) Enzi for Paul amendment #271 (ACA repeal) Donnelly motion to commit (protecting Medicaid)
With healthcare actually happening I don't think this will happen before the middle of next week.

Congress has other things on its plate this week. And, it seems a few more questions are being raised about Wray.  Additionally, Trump seems to be moving toward getting rid of Sessions and Mueller, which is creating increasing tension about a Constitutional crisis -- which Wray would be in the middle of. Trump is also tweeting his complaints about McCabe, the acting FBI director. And Rosenstein, the assistant AG, is also in a precarious position. Recent news reports have some interesting OSINT: “Liberal groups: Delay FBI director vote until Trump promises to keep special counsel,” Politico, July 25. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/25/delay-fbi-director-confirmation-christopher-wray-democrats-240938 “Christie's Hiring of FBI Nominee as Bridgegate Attorney Raises Questions,” WNYC News, July 24. http://www.wnyc.org/story/ethics-question-christies-hiring-fbi-director-nominee-bridgegate-attorney/ “Sessions' allies say Trump using Twitter attacks to force resignation,” Reuters news service, July 25. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-sessions-idUSKBN1AA21V

“Trump escalates shame campaign against Sessions,” Politico, July 25. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/25/trump-jeff-sessions-will-he-resign-240930 “Poll: Americans split 42%-42% on impeaching Trump,” USA Today, July 24. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/07/24/impeach-donald-trump-poll-americans-split-remove-president/501871001/ “Public Evenly Divided over Impeachment of Donald Trump: USA Today/iMediaEthics Poll,” iMediaEthics, July 24. http://www.imediaethics.org/imediaethics-usatoday-poll-public-divided-impeachment-donald-trump/ “Trump doubts Russia would have left evidence of hacking, but US spies say Moscow left it on purpose,” Business Insider, July 23. http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-scaramucci-russia-experts-hacking-2017-7 “Trump's Son-in-Law Answers More Questions on Russia Contacts,” Voice of America, July 25. https://www.voanews.com/a/trump-son-in-law-faces-more-questions-on-russia-contacts/3957960.html
Not looking good with the obsession to repeal healthcare.

Democratic groups: Delay FBI director vote until Trump promises to keep special counsel The groups want the White House to protect the FBI director and his agency from ‘political interference.’ By Edward-Isaac Dovere 07/25/2017 11:51 AM EDT  
http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/25/delay-fbi-director-confirmation-christopher-wray-democrats-240938  THE LETTER, Dated Tuesday July 25th:
http://unitedtoprotectdemocracy.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Senate-letter-re-Wray-Confirmation-draft-07252017.pdf

Looks like Trump is trying to force Sessions and Rosenstein out, to get control over Mueller's investigation. If Mueller is eventually fired, the importance of the FBI investigation will increase. This puts the Democrats in an awkward position - they endorsed Wray earlier, but now may prefer to slow his confirmation a bit, until it's clear what is happening with Sessions/Rosenstein/Mueller. So the chances of a cloture vote increase, which would push confirmation to next week. By the way, July 31 is shown as a non-work day on the Senate's calendar.

Start off with a forecast 50/50
Variable 1: Senate focused on Healthcare +5% After 01AUG
Variable 2: Historical confirmation times +5% pre 01Aug
Point 1: That's an average of 20.833 days 
Clarence M. Kelly's 19 days from nominated to confirmed (nominated 08JUN73-confirmed 27JUN73) 
William H. Webster's 20 days from nominated to confirmed (nomination 20JAN78-confirmed 09FEB78) 
William S. Sessions 16 days from nominated to confirmed (nomination 09SEP87-confirmed 25SEP87) 
Louis J. Freeh 17 days from nominated to confirmed (nominated 20JUL93-confirmed 06AUG93) 
Robert Mueller's 15 days from nominated to confirmed (nominated 18JUL01-confirmed 02AUG01) 
(See "https://fas.org/sgp/crs/natsec/RS20963.pdf" for dates of nomination and confirmation.) 
James Comey's 38 days (nominated 21JUN13-confirmed 29July13)
Variable 3: Historical time Deputy Directors hold interim Director position: +5% pre 01Aug
Point 1: Historical time between new FBI directors "about 70 days on average for the five most recent Acting Directors". 
Point 2: McCabe started 09MAY17+70 days = approximately 16JUL17. 
(Quote from: https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/fbi-director-job-openings-usually-get-filled-quickly)
Variable 4: Same party in control of nomination & confirmation process +2.5% pre 01Aug
Point 1: President and Senate are both Republican held.
Variable 5: Only need 51 members to confirm +2.5% pre 01Aug
Point 1: According to precedence and law the director of the FBI confirmation requires a simple majority vote. 
Variable 5: Opposition party cannot filibuster confirmation vote +2.5% pre 01Aug  Point 1: According to precedence and law the director of the FBI confirmation cannot be filibustered.
*UPDATES 1: 
Variable 6: Senor Democratic leaders (Dianne Feinstein) support building for Wray's nomination +5% pre 01Aug  Point 1: Dianne Feinstein is the 2nd highest ranking member of the Judiciary Committee. A purely rational Senate (Yes, Yes, I know it doesn’t act this way in reality) would support the findings of a unified Judiciary Committee supported nominee.
*UPDATES 2: 
Variable 7: Senior Democrats from the Judiciary Committee, various organizations, FBI & law enforcement centric are endorsing Wray. +2.5% pre 01Aug
*Update 3: 
Variable 7: The time remaining factor. +6.5% pre-01Aug 
*Update 4:
Modification of Variable 7: The time remaining factor. +1.9% pre-01Aug As time goes by, it becomes less likely that Christopher Wray will be confirmed director of FBI ((Days remaining in July)^1.15)/.25 (an arbitrary figure I selected to make my formula work-let’s call it the month/week multiplier). So July 14 = (17 day ^1.15)/.25=6.5%+pre-01Aug. I will update this daily with the new amount. 
Point 1: I cannot think of a way to capture how as the time ticks down and no confirmation scheduled or performed the likelihood ticks down as well.
*Unknowns - This is basically my internal banter in trying to identify all variables that might contribute to increasing or decreasing the likelihood of a pre/post 01Aug confirmation. 
Will there be ethical issues surrounding Wray’s confirmation? One would assume he would be of impeccable ethical standing to be considered for his position. So it is highly (90%) unlikely there will be any evidence to conclusively state he doesn't possess the ethical standing to be director of the FBI. 
But can political wrangling concerned with the Russia investigation and firing of former FBI director cause delays in the confirmation process along the ethical front? Possible (50%). +1% post 01Aug 
Please this analysis was done fairly hastily. If anyone can poke holes in it I would appreciate that as it helps me in the long run. Or if anyone can add other data points that increase / decrease the forecast it would be greatly appreciated.

No movement on scheduling a vote for Wray. They can try to hold a floor vote later today after the health care debacle, or possibly tomorrow. If any Dem signals a filibuster, McConnell can invoke cloture (assuming the votes are there), which starts a 30 hour countdown. If they maintain their recess, they can push this as far as Thursday to invoke cloture with a vote on Monday, which would get us resolution on this question.  But since the Senate doesn't seem inclined to help me with my forecasts here, this is becoming increasingly unlikely, especially if today turns out to be a train wreck. Dropping my forecast more.

The Senate generally only sits in floor sessions a few days a week, and there are rules about how far ahead something has to be put on the calendar (although they are easily suspended).  They're pretty much out of time to get this listed and voted on, especially since M. Petits-Doigts and the distinguished Senators are much distracted by the Trumpcare issue.  And of course since the FBI work under the Justice Department, confirmation calculations must be adjusted now to include the imminent sacking of the Attorney General, Rod Rosenstein, and Robert Mueller.

I don't see any news reports of plans to confirm Wray this week. So it may be after Aug. 1. Related OSINT below indicates Wray will have several complex challenges ahead of him as FBI director: “Our coming constitutional crisis,” Boston Globe, July 24. https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2017/07/24/our-coming-constitutional-crisis/JO9bm7sPqOA0jaYIeDpREJ/story.html “If President Trump fires Robert Mueller, we're headed for a constitutional crisis,” Los Angeles Times on Chicago Tribune, July 23. http://www.chicagotribune.com/ct-trump-fire-robert-mueller-20170724-story.html “A Constitutional Crisis Is Inevitable,” Slate, July 23. http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/the_good_fight/2017/07/we_re_headed_for_a_constitutional_crisis.html “President Trump Calls the Russia Investigation a 'Witch Hunt.' Paul Ryan Disagrees,” Associated Press on TIME magazine, July 24. http://time.com/4871110/paul-ryan-robert-mueller-investigation-trump-russia/ “Trump insiders face congressional investigators as president mulls pardons,” McClatchy newspapers/news service, July 23. http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/congress/article163232073.html “Trump's Son-In-Law Kushner Says 'No Improper Contacts' With Russians,” Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, July 24. https://www.rferl.org/a/kushner-russia-senate-committee/28634536.html “Trump Son-in-Law Denies Collusion With Moscow,” Voice of America, July 24. https://www.voanews.com/a/trump-son-in-law-russia-proble/3956398.html “For Trump and Putin, Sanctions Are a Setback Both Sought to Avoid,” New York Times, July 23. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/23/world/europe/trump-putin-sanctions-hacking.html “Trump DOJ nominee used to represent Russian bank with ties to Putin,” The Hill, July 24. http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/343489-trump-doj-nominee-used-to-represent-russian-bank-with-ties-to-putin “What's the real story on President Trump and Russia?” CNN, July 23. http://www.cnn.com/2017/07/23/opinions/who-is-the-real-trump-opinion-zelizer/index.html “Is Tillerson Getting Ready to Quit?” U.S. News & World Report, July 24. https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-07-24/rex-tillerson-frustrated-with-white-house-prompts-rexit-rumors

Adjusting down. Whispers on the Hill are that the Senate might change its recess back to it's original start date (after this Friday, 28 July) given the almost assured failure of the health care vote. That still gives the Senate 4 days to conduct a floor vote if they invoke cloture (ending the debate - requires 51 Senators for confirmation) on Wray this afternoon. If there's not cloture after this afternoon's administrative proceedings, this becomes increasingly likely to happen in September, regardless of the recess dates as that only provides 1 additional day for this question. Watching out for any formal news of the Senate's recess. Check the Senate's webpage (https://www.senate.gov/) for the cloture vote.

Yertle the Turtle (R-Ky), the distinguished Senate Majority Leader with no majority, seems to be dragging his feet on this, presumably so he can fail once again to get a healthcare elimination bill passed.  Seems an odd choice--he could pick up a cheap win for himself and President Littlefingers by calling this nomination up tomorrow and getting it passed by a large and bipartisan margin.

Because it might be a busy week for Congress, Wray's full-confirmation vote could be bumped to August. Quite a lot of new information has come out since Wray's committee hearing regarding Russia's activities.  Additionally, the special counsel's investigation is moving forward robustly. Trump himself and some of the developments in the Trump administration also seem relevant to the investigations. Wray is going to be in an interesting position. Trump may try to fire Mueller or interfere with the investigation in other ways (such as talking pardons for potential witnesses who might cooperate with Mueller's investigators). Recent news items include some OSINT: “Former CIA chief: Officials should ‘refuse’ to fire Mueller if Trump asks,” The Hill, July 22. http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/343271-former-cia-chief-officials-should-refuse-to-fire-mueller-if “Trump officials: Russia meddled in the election,” The Hill, July 20. http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/343063-trump-officials-russia-meddled-in-the-election “NSA chief: Now is 'not the best time' for US-Russia cyber unit,” The Hill, July 22. http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/343312-nsa-chief-now-is-not-the-best-time-for-us-russia-cyber-unit “Russia sanctions deal reached without changes Trump sought,” Politico, July 22. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/21/russia-sanctions-deal-trump-congress-240814 “Congress reaches bipartisan agreement on sweeping Russia sanctions,” CNBC, July 22. http://www.cnbc.com/2017/07/22/congress-reaches-bipartisan-agreement-on-sweeping-russia-sanctions.html “Jeb Bush calls out Republicans who criticized Obama over Russia, but have been silent on the Trump-Russia probe,” Business Insider, July 22. http://www.businessinsider.com/jeb-bush-blasts-trump-and-republicans-over-their-handling-of-the-russia-invesetigation-2017-7 “Former spy officials criticize Trump’s stance on Russia at Aspen Security Forum,” Associated Press on Denver Post, July 21. http://www.denverpost.com/2017/07/21/donald-trump-russia-spy-officials-aspen-security-forum/ “Exclusive: Read the Previously Undisclosed Plan to Counter Russian Hacking on Election Day,” TIME magazine, July 20. http://time.com/4865798/russia-hacking-election-day-obama-plan/

I have been wracking, or perhaps racking, my brain to think of a reason why this wouldn't happen.  Can't come up with anything, but these days just because there is no reason for something doesn't even mean it's particularly improbable.  In a country run by grownups this confirmation would occur last Tuesday or so.  Still, bumping up some more.  Will I ever learn?  Stay tuned.

It is past the first date so that's gone.
He easily cleared committees with bipartisan support and McConnell indicated the intention to have him confirmed before the August recess.

With a week to go before Aug. 1, the full Senate may not vote to confirm Wray before that date. The Senate has a lot on its plate. I believe they are planning some full-Senate votes on health care. Although the health care vote reportedly may fail in certain respects, a vote on Wray would be somewhat of a positive move forward for the Senate and the country.  Lots of eyes on Wray because he is walking into a very serious and complex situation. Sessions may be out soon and Trump would appoint a new AG. Trump reportedly wants Mueller fired and the Russia investigation to be limited. The Russia investigations appear to be moving quickly and seemingly becoming more serious every day. Wray will be in the middle of it politically and regarding the FBI's counter-intelligence activities. Related OSINT in the news (see article referencing former DNI Clapper, last article below): “Report: Sessions Discussed Policy With Russian Envoy,” Voice of America, July 22. https://www.voanews.com/a/report-sessions-discussed-policy-with-russian-ambassador/3954676.html “New Reports Say Trump Team Exploring Pardons to Undercut Mueller,” Voice of America, July 20. https://www.voanews.com/a/reports-trump-team-exploring-pardons-to-undercut-mueller/3953280.html “Did Trump Campaign Collude with Russia to Defeat Republican Opponents in GOP Primary?” Just Security, July 18. https://www.justsecurity.org/43270/trump-campaign-collude-russia-defeat-republican-opponents-gop-primary “Manafort Was in Debt to Pro-Russia Interests, Cyprus Records Show,” New York Times, July 19. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/us/politics/paul-manafort-russia-trump.html “U.S. Treasury Accuses Exxon Mobil Of 2014 Violation Of Russia Sanctions,” Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, July 20. https://www.rferl.org/a/us-treasury-accuses-exxon-violating-russian-sanctions/28629213.html  “Trump Says He Has ‘Complete Power’ to Pardon,” New York Times, July 22. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/22/us/politics/donald-trump-jeff-sessions.html “Former spy chiefs tear into Trump,” Politico, July 21. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/21/spy-chiefs-rip-trump-240828

Wray has been recommended to the Senate floor by a unanimous vote from the Senate Judiciary Committee (https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/07/20/senate-panel-votes-confirm-christopher-wray-new-fbi-director/495001001/).   Still holding at 80-20 until McConnell schedules a vote that is before August 1 (not merely before the August recess). @danbell7819's comment is good: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/538917

As mentioned by @JMR2017, here's the Senate Executive Calendar (Wray on pg 10): https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/executive_calendar/xcalv.pdf. I'd anticipate that they move to invoke cloture on Wray Monday after voting on Bernhardt, following up with a vote on Tuesday. However, they could delay the cloture vote until Tuesday as well.  Either way, it's very likely Wray will be confirmed by the end of next week.

Chris Wray was just confirmed by the senate judiciary committee in a unanimous decision on July 20. Neil Gorsuch judiciary committee meeting was in march and wasn't approved until april. SCOTUS candidates higher level of scrutiny (no pun intended). Similar timeline but this should go faster due to position. Scheduling forecast it seems like at this point.

Senate Floor Schedule Monday, Jul 24, 2017 4:00 p.m.: Convene and proceed to executive session to resume consideration of the nomination of David Bernhardt, of Virginia, to be Deputy Secretary of the Interior.
____________________________________________-
Comment:
The US Senate convenes late (EST) according to the Senate Executive Calendar. Wray is now listed on the Nominations page of the Senate Executive calendar following today's Judiciary committee vote. Rules require that the nomination minimally sit for one day before a Motion to Proceed to a floor vote can happen.  However nothing happens over the long Congress weekends as they take off on Thursdays and apparently come back late on Monday.
Other rule considerations get added such as unanimous consent votes to proceed. Check Tuesday's calendar when it gets updated on Monday.
Nothing is more certain than nothing happening in the Trump administration.  I fill this out on July 20, 2017.
Wray was confirmed in committee, so now it's a scheduling issue: http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/20/christopher-wray-nomination-approved-senate-judiciary-240754

A full vote on Wray's confirmation is planned before the August recess. However, that recess has been pushed back further past Aug. 1.  Lots of developments in the news that would affect Wray and the position of FBI director under Trump (see below). Recent news reports contain some useful OSINT: “McConnell to set up vote for Trump’s FBI pick before recess,” The Hill, July 18. http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/342492-mcconnell-to-set-up-vote-for-trumps-fbi-pick-before-recess “McConnell plans vote for FBI nominee Wray before August recess,” Politico, July 17. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/17/mcconnell-plans-wray-vote-before-recess-240650 “Trump turns against his attorney general over Russia,” Politico, July 19. http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/19/trump-turns-on-sessions-240740 “Trump Lashes Out at Jeff Sessions,” U.S. News & World Report, July 20. https://www.usnews.com/news/ken-walshs-washington/articles/2017-07-20/donald-trump-lashes-out-at-jeff-sessions “Trump Draws 'Red Line' for Mueller at Family Finances Unrelated to Russia,” Voice of America, July 20. https://www.voanews.com/a/trump-sessions-russia-recusal-new-york-times/3951596.html “Trump warns Mueller against looking into his family finances apart from Russia investigation,” CNBC, July 20. http://www.cnbc.com/2017/07/20/trump-warns-mueller-against-looking-into-his-family-finances-apart-from-russia-investigation.html “Mueller Expands Probe to Trump Business Transactions,” Bloomberg news, July 20. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/mueller-is-said-to-expand-probe-to-trump-business-transactions “Trump suggests James Comey tried to use explosive Russia dossier as leverage to keep his job,” Business Insider, July 20. http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-russia-comey-firing-dossier-steele-2017-7
Wray was voted out of committee 20-0, I don't see any obstacles to his confirmation at this point except for scheduling.

Happy Wray Day! Committee vote for confirmation is today at 9:30am. Assuming he passes, we'll find out if his floor vote, which he should also pass, even with McCain's absence, is scheduled before 1 August.
The average time for nomination post-Hoover was 20 days, Trump took the longest so far with 38 days.

Republicans need a win after the failure to repeal and replace/repeal Obamacare.
 This is a fairly easy target.  McConnell already has stated he will schedule a vote before the August recess (http://www.politico.com/story/2017/07/17/mcconnell-plans-wray-vote-before-recess-240650).

Clips from Beast article"
"So Graham gamely read him one of the emails that Don Jr. himself tweeted, an email where a music publicist told the would-be president’s son that the Russian government was looking to give him research that would hurt Clinton.
“Should Donald Trump Jr. have taken that meeting?” Graham asked.
“Well, Senator, I don’t – I, I, I’m hearing for the first your description of it so I’m not really in a position to speak to it, I gather that special counsel Mueller will –,” Wray began.
Graham cut him off.
“Well, let me ask you this,” he said in his South Carolina drawl. “If I got a call from somebody saying the Russian government wants to help Lindsey Graham get reelected, they’ve got dirt on Lindsey Graham’s opponent – should I take that meeting?”
Wray paused.
“Well, Senator, I would think you’d want to consult with some good legal advisors before you did that,” he said.
“So the answer is, should I call the FBI?” Graham retorted.
“I think it would be wise to let the FBI know,” Wray replied.
Graham seemed frustrated.
“You’re going to be the director of the FBI, pal!” he said, raising his voice. “So here’s what I want you to tell every politician: If you get a call from somebody suggesting that a foreign government wants to help you by disparaging your opponent, tell us all to call the FBI.”
Wray paused again.
“To the members of this committee,” Wray said slowly, “any threat or effort to interfere with our elections from any nation-state or any non-state actor is the kind of thing the FBI would want to know.”
“Alright, Graham said. “So I’ll take it that we should call you. And that’s a great answer.”

Increasing July likelihood due to postponed recess. McConnell just delayed the Senate's August recess until August 11, providing two extra weeks to get the GOP votes necessary to pass BCRA (https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/mcconnell-delays-august-recess-to-complete-work-on-health-care-bill-other-issues/2017/07/11/1d90e3d2-6647-11e7-9928-22d00a47778f_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-more-top-stories_pp-mcconnell-155pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory). These eases the legislative burden somewhat, and can allow the committees more time to work their specific issues (such as confirming a new FBI director). The Senate R's will still likely try to push to complete BCRA as quickly as possible, as this now cuts into fundraising opportunities for those R's up for reelection in 2018. The Senate still only has 13 days in session (now going to July 31) to confirm Wray (unless McConnell starts requiring legislative work to be done over weekends), but has 17 calendar days (which is what most confirmation timeline averages are based on), which is very plausible. We'll see how Wednesday goes, especially with the explosive new revelations of Trump Jr. and Wray's previous private sector work on behalf of some Russian companies, but it's looking better for Grassley to get his wish of confirmation before recess. Also, expect the new version of the BCRA to drop tomorrow morning (or possibly tonight) to distract media attention from the hearing, and don't be surprised if Trump holds a presser to discuss something at the same time as the hearing (Russia, not Russia, cyber with Russia, no cyber with Russia, Marine Corps aircraft loss, the failed FBI's old HQ, the corrupt Bernie Sanders, Mika Brzezinski being a woman, etc.) to try and distract the media as well (although the recent trend has been to prohibit cameras during WH pressers, so maybe not). In short, enough GOP major muscle movement in the last few days to make this more favorable.

Apparently 65% of all Trump nominations have been filibustered, albeit for a relatively short time since nominations only require 51 votes anyway. I went through the list of the high profile nominees who were filibustered and from their first hearing to final Senate confirmation, an average of 22 days elapsed. For Christopher Wray, there are just 19 available days from July 12 to the last day of the month. Therefore, this would need to be a priority in order to beat the average time. For those higher profile nominees who weren't filibustered (Haley, Pompeo, Kelley, Mattis) the average time from their first hearing to confirmation was 9 days. The Wed. hearing will signal potential problems or not.

Following up on thread with @Anneinak and @JMR2017 it seems as though Trump could drag this process out for quite some time. The Federal Vacancies Reform Act of 1998 outlines much of the process for "acting" agency heads, but here's the skinny on it: -Trump, since it's a transition year, has 300 days (from inauguration) to fill vacancies across the Federal government (essentially until mid-November)
-For non-transition vacancies (such as the FBI director) the an acting chief can serve for 210 days (Wikipedia states 120 and 150 days, but I can't access the CRS report it references)
-However, that 210 day clock is essentially postponed indefinitely once a candidate has been nominated, meaning that if the Senate slow-rolls the nomination for several months (a la Merrick Garland), the acting could be in the post well past the 210 mark, especially if the nomination is made close to the deadline
-If the Senate rejects or returns, or the President withdraws, the nominee, the clock restarts and the acting gets another 210 days
-Once a second nomination is made, the acting can then remain in post indefinitely while the nominee is being considered
-Only if the second nominee is rejected, returned, or withdrawn, or if the President fails to make a second nomination with the allotted time, is the position required to go vacant https://www.gsa.gov/graphics/admin/Vacancies_Reform_Act1998.pdf
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Vacancies_Reform_Act_of_1998 However, it's unclear what the consequences of allowing the position to go vacant are, beyond the fact that anyone in an acting capacity is no longer able to take any legally binding action. So if the FBI director position is vacated by not meeting the timeline, McCabe no longer has any ability to take enforceable action. Which seems like it might actually be a boon to Trump, as it would effectively hamstring the FBI's investigation as certain decisions are required from the director.  This would seem like it would come at great political cost, but in today's environment, it might be the most political savvy move to leave the position vacant by either failing to meet the deadlines or nominating politically repugnant candidates, thus further entangling the investigation into partisan politics. The opportunity cost for Trump in that case, however, would be that he'll have to stage more photo shoots for letter signings to appease his base's call for action, as such decision would likely engulf the Senate in the process. Historically, it has taken 19-38 days between the nomination of an FBI director and the Senate confirmation (thanks @Anneinak). However, this was in the good old days of more bipartisan spirit on the Hill. Moreover, this time the Senate will exercise a lot of scrutiny, given the ongoing FBI investigation. So let's say we cut the bottom half of this range and assume it will take 29-38 days between nomination and confirmation. This means confirmation before July 1 is out of question already, and confirmation before August 1 will be possible if a not-too-outrageous nomination is in place by Friday, June 30 or so. Moreover, a nomination before June 23 will have a high change of passing before August 1.  Other factors to consider: (i) a truly independent and professional candidate can be confirmed faster than 29 days; (ii) a candidate know mainly for his personal loyalty to Trump may not be passed at all. Judging by the continuing search, however, the White House is aware of this second possibility, which reduces the probability of such nomination.

Frances Townsend: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frances_Townsend
Townsend began her prosecutorial career in 1985, serving as an Assistant District Attorney in Brooklyn, New York. She gained the support and mentorship of federal prosecutors Rudolph Giuliani and Louis Freeh. In 1988, she was hired by Giuliani for the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York where she worked on white-collar crime. Townsend also ran the office's organized crime unit, where she conducted one-on-one interviews with members of the Gambino crime family.
Townsend moved to the Justice Department in the early 1990s to work on international legal matters. In 1991, she worked in the Office of the Attorney General to assist in establishing the newly created Office of International Programs, the predecessor to the Executive Office for National Security. In December 1993, she joined the Criminal Division where she served as Chief of Staff to the Assistant Attorney General, where she took part in establishing the Division's international training and rule of law programs.
During the Clinton administration, Townsend served in a series of positions at the Justice Department, eventually working as intelligence policy counsel for Attorney General Janet Reno. She served as Director of the Office of International Affairs in the Criminal Division from November 1995 until November 1997, when she was appointed Acting Deputy Assistant Attorney General. Townsend was appointed Counsel for Intelligence Policy in March 1998, heading the office of Intelligence Policy and Review, whose various functions included approving intelligence-gathering activities related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Townsend managed the Justice Department's Office of Intelligence Policy and Review until 2001. She was one of Reno's key advisers, acting as a "back channel" between the attorney general and FBI Special Agent John P. O'Neill, who was also her friend. The incoming Bush administration did not opt to keep Townsend on. Instead, she served as Assistant Commandant for Intelligence for the United States Coast Guard. While she was on maternity leave during the September 11 attacks in 2001, Townsend assisted the Coast Guard in updating intelligence legislation to switch the branch's priority from drug smuggling to the vulnerability of U.S. ports.
Despite worries about Townsend's past as a Democratic appointee, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice hired her for the National Security Council in Spring 2003 at the urging of counterterrorism chief John A. Gordon and Homeland Security Advisor Richard A. Clarke. In December 2003, she coordinated government terrorism responses that led to the grounding of flights from Europe during the holiday season. She was appointed Assistant to the President for Homeland Security and Counterterrorism on May 28, 2004. During her tenure, she oversaw an intelligence reorganization and conducted the first post-9/11 review of the White House's anti-terrorism campaign. Townsend served as the public face of the Bush administration while it was under criticism for allegedly overreacting to dated intelligence in its decision to raise terrorist threat levels during an election season. She also inspected Iraq's Abu Ghraib prison as an envoy of President Bush. Townsend was tapped to implement broad changes in the intelligence community recommended by a presidential commission headed by former Senator Chuck Robb and U.S. District Judge Laurence Silberman.
Townsend then served in the United States Department of Justice, including a stint as Counsel to the Attorney General for Intelligence Policy in the George W. Bush administration. In May 2007, she was appointed "National Continuity Coordinator" under the auspices of National Security Presidential Directive (NSPD) 51.
As of this date, Townsend serves as an Advisory Board member for the Partnership for a Secure America. Other memberships include the Council on Foreign Relations and the Leadership Council for Concordia. Frances Fragos married lawyer John Michael Townsend on October 8, 1994 in an Episcopal ceremony at Manhattan's Church of the Incarnation. As of 2006, they have two children, both sons. With a self-professed "triple type-A" personality, Townsend has been described as having a characteristic bluntness and a "sometimes salty, streetwise style" that once led her coworkers to nickname her "The Hurricane".

Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act authorizes the Intelligence Community to target the communications of non-U.S. persons located outside the United States for foreign intelligence purposes. A key anti-terror tool that has helped to thwart numerous terror plots including the 2009 conspiracy to bomb the New York City subway, Section 702 operations are subject to multiple layers of oversight by all three branches of government.

Unless Trump announces his candidate today before leaving in under an hour, the announcement will likely come after his return at the end of the month. Who he nominates will determine how long the confirmation process is. More contentious candidates will likely slow the process, while universally acclaimed candidates will likely go through quicker. Trump's candidates are averaging 25 days between nomination and confirmation (https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/how-long-confirmations-will-take/), which would put this at the end of June assuming an announcement by 31 May. However, the WH has taken the approach of announcing the candidate, and then completing the necessary vetting. If they follow this approach again, they run the risk of being blindsided by a controversial issue of the candidate or by the candidate's inability to divest of conflicts. Another factor to keep in mind is that the Senate will take off the entire week following Memorial Day, returning to session on 3 June. It is likely, given the toxicity of the AHCA, that the Senate will prioritize confirmation hearings and votes for the FBI director over writing their version of health care reform. However, just because it receives priority doesn't mean it will sail through. The Russia scandal and the assignment of a special prosecutor will likely force Republicans to yield to Democrats' demands of thoroughly vetting the nominee, which could slow down the committee hearings. Once out of committee, the Republicans will likely have to negotiate with the Democrats to ensure some level of bipartisan support to counter the narrative of the new director being a puppet for the party and WH. The confirmation along party lines of a controversial director could result in significant fallout for the Republican party in 2018, especially if it comes across as a means of squashing the investigation. And while the filibuster has been removed for filling vacancies in the administration, the Democrats can threaten a government shutdown in October if they believe the Republicans are not being transparent. (And no, the Dems will not likely suffer for it, much as Reps didn't suffer long term for the 2013 shutdown). For these reasons, I think it will be close to the 1 July date, and favor afterwards more than before. The timing of the announcement and the vetting process will shift the probabilities. After 1 August is not likely, as Congress is on recess for all of August, and will then have to negotiate an FY18 budget (or more likely a CR) in the 3 weeks they have in session in September.

With Trump conducting some interviews this week and saying he could name his pick of the new director as early as later today, things seems to me moving forward at a decent place. Plus, I think the faster it's done the better it looks for Trump and the GOP
